elements.desc:
Element for querying the Google Analytics Core Reporting API.

##### Example

    <google-analytics-query
      ids="ga:1174"
      metrics="ga:sessions"
      dimensions="ga:country"
      sort="-ga:sessions"
      maxResults="5">
    </google-analytics-query>

events.desc: Fired when an error occurs while running a query.

jsdoc.description: Fired when an error occurs while running a query.
jsdoc.orig:
*
         * Fired when an error occurs while running a query.
         *
         * @event analytics-query-error

events.name: analytics-query-error

events.desc: Fired when a query is successfully run and data has been stored.

jsdoc.description: Fired when a query is successfully run and data has been stored.
jsdoc.orig:
*
         * Fired when a query is successfully run and data has been stored.
         *
         * @event analytics-query-success

events.name: analytics-query-success

properties.name: data
properties.desc:
The `data` attribute is the response from a query to the Google
Analytics Core Reporting API. This value will be updated as
subsequent requests are made.

properties.name: dimensions
properties.desc: The `dimensions` attribute is a list of comma-separated dimensions for your Analytics data, such as ga:browser,ga:city. See the Core Reporting API parameter reference for more details.

properties.name: endDate
properties.desc: The `endDate` attribute is the end date for fetching Analytics data. Requests can specify an end date formatted as YYYY-MM-DD, or as a relative date (e.g., today, yesterday, or NdaysAgo where N is a positive integer). See the Core Reporting API parameter reference for more details.

properties.name: fields
properties.desc: The `fields` attribute is a selector specifying a subset of fields to include in the response. See the Core Reporting API parameter reference for more details.

properties.name: filters
properties.desc: The `filters` attribute is dimension or metric filters that restrict the data returned for your request. See the Core Reporting API parameter reference for more details.

properties.name: getData
properties.desc: Query the Google Analytics Core Reporting API.

properties.name: getDataResponseHandler
handleResponse
properties.desc:
The callback for the query run in `getData`. This is a separate
function so subclasses can alter how the response is handled.

properties.name: ids
properties.desc: The `ids` attribute is the unique table ID of the form ga:XXXX, where XXXX is the Analytics view (profile) ID for which the query will retrieve the data. See the Core Reporting API parameter reference for more details. Note: you can find out the `ids` value for any of your Google Analytics account using the Google Analytics query explorer.

properties.name: loading
properties.desc: true if data is getting loaded

properties.name: maxResults
properties.desc: The `maxResults` attribute is the maximum number of rows to include in the response. See the Core Reporting API parameter reference for more details.

properties.name: metrics
properties.desc: The `metrics` attribute is a list of comma-separated metrics, such as ga:sessions,ga:bounces. See the Core Reporting API parameter reference for more details.

properties.name: output
properties.desc: The `output` attribute sets the desired output type for the Analytics data returned in the response. Acceptable values are json and dataTable. See the Core Reporting API parameter reference for more details.

properties.name: samplingLevel
properties.desc: The `samplingLevel` attribute sets the desired sampling level. Allowed Values: `DEFAULT`, `FASTER`, `HIGHER_PRECISION`. See the Core Reporting API parameter reference for more details.

properties.name: segment
properties.desc: The `segment` attribute segments the data returned for your request. See the Core Reporting API parameter reference for more details.

properties.name: setData
properties.desc:
setData sets data fetched by getData.
Use it if you override getData response processing

properties.name: setupReady
properties.desc: True if setup is ready

properties.name: sort
properties.desc: The `sort` attribute is a list of comma-separated dimensions and metrics indicating the sorting order and sorting direction for the returned data. See the Core Reporting API parameter reference for more details.

properties.name: startDate
properties.desc: The `startDate` attribute is the start date for fetching Analytics data. Requests can specify a start date formatted as YYYY-MM-DD, or as a relative date (e.g., today, yesterday, or NdaysAgo where N is a positive integer). See the Core Reporting API parameter reference for more details.

properties.name: startIndex
properties.desc: The `startIndex` attribute sets the first row of data to retrieve, starting at 1. Use this parameter as a pagination mechanism along with the max-results parameter. See the Core Reporting API parameter reference for more details.

properties.name: _srcParam
properties.desc: GA team internal variable for analytics purposes.

elements.desc:
Element for displaying the results of a Google Analytics query in a
Google Chart.

##### Example

    <google-analytics-chart
      type="column"
      ids="ga:1174"
      metrics="ga:sessions"
      dimensions="ga:country"
      sort="-ga:sessions"
      maxResults="5">
    </google-analytics-chart>

properties.name: height
properties.desc: Sets the height of the chart on the page.

properties.name: loading
properties.desc: True if the chart is currently loading data.

properties.name: options
properties.desc:
Sets the options for the chart. Example: 
{
  title: "Chart title goes here",
  hAxis: {title: "Categories"},
  vAxis: {title: "Values", minValue: 0, maxValue: 2},
  legend: "none"
};
See Google Visualization API reference (Chart Gallery) for the options available to each chart type.

properties.name: rendered
properties.desc: True after the chart has been rendered for the first time.

properties.name: setupReady
properties.desc: True if setup is ready

properties.name: startDate
properties.desc:
google-analytics-query passthrough properties
See google-analytics-query for documentation
startDate, endDate, data, ids, metrics, dimensions, sort, filters, segment, samplingLevel, startIndex, maxResults

properties.name: type
properties.desc:
Sets the type of the chart.

Should be one of:
- `area`, `bar`, `column`, `line`, `pie`, `geo`.

properties.name: width
properties.desc: Sets the width of the chart on the page.

elements.desc:
Element for selecting the start and end date values for queries inside a
`<google-analytics-dashboard>` element.

##### Example

    <google-analytics-dashboard>

      <google-analytics-date-selector
        startDate="30daysAgo"
        endDate="today">
      </google-analytics-date-selector>

      <google-analytics-chart
        ids="ga:1174"
        metrics="ga:sessions"
        dimensions="ga:date">
      </google-analytics-chart>

    </google-analytics-dashboard>

properties.name: endDate
properties.desc: The `endDate` attribute is the end date for fetching Analytics data. Requests can specify an end date formatted as YYYY-MM-DD, or as a relative date (e.g., today, yesterday, or NdaysAgo where N is a positive integer). See the Core Reporting API parameter reference for more details.

properties.name: maxEndDate
properties.desc:
The `maxEndDate` attribute is used as the `max` attribute on the
end date `<input>`.

properties.name: minStartDate
properties.desc:
The `minStartDate` attribute is used as the `min` attribute on the
start date `<input>`.

properties.name: startDate
properties.desc: The `startDate` attribute is the start date for fetching Analytics data. Requests can specify a start date formatted as YYYY-MM-DD, or as a relative date (e.g., today, yesterday, or NdaysAgo where N is a positive integer). See the Core Reporting API parameter reference for more details.

elements.desc:
Element for selecting the view ID (ids) value for queries inside a
`<google-analytics-dashboard>` element.

##### Example

    <google-analytics-dashboard>

      <google-analytics-view-selector></google-analytics-view-selector>

      <google-analytics-chart
        metrics="ga:sessions"
        dimensions="ga:date">
      </google-analytics-chart>

    </google-analytics-dashboard>

events.desc: Fired when the users changes the view

jsdoc.description: Fired when the users changes the view
jsdoc.orig:
*
       * Fired when the users changes the view
       *
       * @param {Object} query The updated query params.
       * @event analytics-dashboard-control-change

events.name: analytics-dashboard-control-change

properties.name: account
properties.desc: The `account` attribute is the currently selected account.

properties.name: fireChangeEvent
properties.desc: Fire a change event passing all the currently stored data.

properties.name: ids
properties.desc: The `ids` attribute, when found is used to preselect the chosen account, property, and view. See the Core Reporting API parameter reference for more details.

properties.name: property
properties.desc: The `property` attribute is the currently selected property.

properties.name: setupReady
properties.desc: True if setup is ready

properties.name: summaries
properties.desc: The `summaries` attribute contains an account summaries utility object with various helper methods for quickly getting account data. See the Github repo for more details.

properties.name: updateAccount
properties.desc:
The `updateAccount` method is bound to the change event on the
account `<select>`. It updates the property and view `<select>`s based
on the new account data. It also updates the `ids` attribute.

properties.name: updateProperty
properties.desc:
The `updateProperty` method is bound to the change event on the
property `<select>`. It updates the view `<select>` based
on the new property data. It also updates the `ids` attribute.

properties.name: updateView
properties.desc:
The `updateView` method is bound to the change event on the
view `<select>`. It updates the `ids` attribute.

properties.name: view
properties.desc: The `view` attribute is the currently selected view.

properties.name: viewChanged
properties.desc: this.view = Path.get('views[0]').getValueFrom(newProperty);

elements.desc:
Element for grouping Google Analytics elements together.

`<google-analytics-chart>` elements inside a `<google-analytics-dashboard>`
element will automatically update as control elements (e.g.
`<google-analytics-view-selector>` or `<google-analytics-date-selector>`)
update query parameters.

##### Example

    <google-analytics-dashboard>

      <google-analytics-view-selector></google-analytics-view-selector>
      <google-analytics-date-selector></google-analytics-date-selector>

      <google-analytics-chart
        metrics="ga:sessions"
        dimensions="ga:country"
        sort="-ga:sessions"
        maxResults="5"
        chartType="column">
      </google-analytics-chart>

    </google-analytics-dashboard>

properties.name: authorized
properties.desc: True if user has been authorized

properties.name: query
properties.desc:
The `query` attribute represents the internal query object of this
dashboard. It is updated when control elements fire the
`analytics-dashboard-control-change` event and pass along query data.

properties.name: queryUpdated
properties.desc:
The `queryUpdated` method is the callback for whenever the
`analytics-dashboard-control-change` event is fired. It updates the
query attribute, which is then sent to child charts.

params.name: event
params.desc: The event with the query data.

properties.name: updateChildren
properties.desc:
The `updateChildren` method updates each of this dashboards
`<google-analytics-chart>` element with its current query value.

elements.desc:
google-analytics-loader is used internally by elements that need to know api state, and user state.

Loads gapi.client.analytics, and watches user signed-in state.

properties.name: allReady
properties.desc: True when user is authorized, and api is loaded

properties.name: apiReady
properties.desc: True when api is loaded

properties.name: authorized
properties.desc: True when user is authorized

google-analytics-query.desc:
Element for querying the Google Analytics Core Reporting API.

##### Example

    <google-analytics-query
      ids="ga:1174"
      metrics="ga:sessions"
      dimensions="ga:country"
      sort="-ga:sessions"
      maxResults="5">
    </google-analytics-query>

events.desc: Fired when an error occurs while running a query.

jsdoc.orig:
*
         * Fired when an error occurs while running a query.
         *
         * @event analytics-query-error

events.name: analytics-query-error

         *
         * @event analytics-query-success

events.name: analytics-query-success

google-analytics-dashboard.desc:
Element for grouping Google Analytics elements together.

`<google-analytics-chart>` elements inside a `<google-analytics-dashboard>`
element will automatically update as control elements (e.g.
`<google-analytics-view-selector>` or `<google-analytics-date-selector>`)
update query parameters.

##### Example

    <google-analytics-dashboard>

      <google-analytics-view-selector></google-analytics-view-selector>
      <google-analytics-date-selector></google-analytics-date-selector>

      <google-analytics-chart
        metrics="ga:sessions"
        dimensions="ga:country"
        sort="-ga:sessions"
        maxResults="5"
        chartType="column">
      </google-analytics-chart>

    </google-analytics-dashboard>

properties.name: authorized
properties.desc: True if user has been authorized

properties.name: query
properties.desc:
The `query` attribute represents the internal query object of this
dashboard. It is updated when control elements fire the
`analytics-dashboard-control-change` event and pass along query data.

properties.name: queryUpdated
properties.desc:
The `queryUpdated` method is the callback for whenever the
`analytics-dashboard-control-change` event is fired. It updates the
query attribute, which is then sent to child charts.

params.name: event
params.desc: The event with the query data.

properties.name: updateChildren
properties.desc:
The `updateChildren` method updates each of this dashboards
`<google-analytics-chart>` element with its current query value.
